title: [aerospace] High Employee Turnover Risk in Operations Department

title: [aerospace] Potential Over-Reliance on Specific Airlines
description: The dataset shows a concentration of maintenance records for specific airlines, such as KE and OZ. This may indicate a risk if these airlines face operational issues.
recommendations: Diversify maintenance contracts across more airlines
Monitor the performance of heavily relied-upon airlines
business_impact: Over-reliance could lead to service disruptions if a primary airline encounters issues.

title: [aerospace] Frequent Minor Delays Recorded
description: The delay records indicate a significant number of minimal delays (23 out of 51 records), which could suggest inefficiencies in scheduling or operational processes.
recommendations: Implement real-time tracking systems to mitigate delays
business_impact: Frequent delays can affect customer satisfaction and operational efficiency.

title: [aerospace] Limited Shift Patterns for Employees
description: The majority of employees (50 out of 70) are on a rotational shift pattern, which may lead to employee fatigue and reduced productivity over time.
recommendations: Evaluate shift patterns for potential adjustments
Consider introducing more flexible scheduling options
business_impact: Fatigue can lead to increased errors and reduced operational efficiency.

title: [aerospace] High Employee Turnover Risk in Operations
description: The Operations department has the highest number of employees (14), but the average salary grade is relatively low (G06 and G07). This could indicate potential dissatisfaction among employees, leading to high turnover rates.
business_impact: High turnover can lead to increased recruitment and training costs, affecting operational efficiency.

title: [aerospace] Concentration of Maintenance Workload
description: The maintenance workload is heavily concentrated among a few mechanics, with 'EMP019' and 'EMP020' handling 11 maintenance tasks each. This could lead to burnout and decreased performance.
recommendations: Hire additional mechanics to balance workload
business_impact: Over-reliance on specific employees can lead to operational disruptions if they are unavailable.

title: [aerospace] Aging Fleet Concerns
description: The average founding year of airlines is 1973.70, indicating that many airlines may be operating older aircraft, which can lead to higher maintenance costs and potential safety risks.
business_impact: An aging fleet can lead to increased operational costs and safety concerns, impacting overall profitability.

title: [aerospace] Frequent Delays with Minimal Compensation
description: The average delay time is 10.49 minutes, with a significant number of delays categorized as 'MINIMAL'. However, the average passenger compensation is only 0.04, indicating that the airline may not be adequately compensating passengers for delays.
recommendations: Implement better communication strategies during delays
business_impact: Inadequate compensation can lead to customer dissatisfaction and damage the airline's reputation.

title: [aerospace] Potential for Baggage Handling Damage
description: The average damage reported for baggage handling is 0.02, which, while low, indicates that there are instances of damage that could affect customer satisfaction and operational efficiency.
recommendations: Train staff on proper baggage handling techniques
business_impact: Damage to baggage can lead to customer complaints and financial claims, impacting the airline's reputation.
